awd_titl_txt: Numerical Methods for Multiscale Inverse Problems and Applications to Sonar Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
The principal investigator aims to develop mathematical and computational tools for data-driven research by using theoretically-sound prediction models and adaptive numerical methods that capture intrinsic features of complex physical processes. This research project is intended to provide new guarantees for the solvability of a class of inverse problems important in mathematics, commercial industries, and defense operations. The project will involve undergraduate and graduate students, who will receive training in numerical methods, analysis, and scientific applications. 

The principal investigator will pursue an original strategy for extracting details from large scale datasets using a new class of efficient methods that exploit problem-dependent features of processes occurring on multiple scales. The design of numerical schemes is adaptable to qualitative scientific knowledge and has the potential to significantly enhance the accessibility and performance of current inversion methods. The basis of the approach is the selection of a low-dimensional parameter that describes key microscopic details and the development of numerical methods that retain an intrinsic knowledge of parameter values while solving large-scale models, substantially reducing computational costs. Deliverables of the project will be the new methodology, as well as scientific applications to large scale inverse problems in sonar imaging, where the main challenge is to capture the appropriate physics while maintaining computational time and memory demands acceptable for current computer architectures.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to develop mathematical and computational tools for data-driven research by using theoretically-sound prediction models and adaptive numerical methods that capture intrinsic features of complex physical processes. New guarantees for the solvability of a class of inverse problems have a great deal of importance in mathematics, commercial industries, and defense operations. 

The funded research studied equations that govern sound waves that are used in sonar imaging to identify important properties of the seafloor. The main challenge is to capture the appropriate physics while maintaining computational time and memory demands acceptable for current computer architectures. This work produced studies that that used optimization and machine learning techniques to classify realistic synthetic sonar data. The techniques are adaptable to qualitative scientific knowledge and have the potential to enhance the accessibility and performance of current inversion methods in other fields such as medical imaging and geophysics.

Another main outcome of this work was a fundamental study of how signals that oscillate at multiple frequencies must be sampled in order to gain efficiency and robustness. Addressing this issue produced two new discoveries in the area of harmonic analysis, and a new methodology for explicitly reconstructing high dimensional bandlimited functions.

Two studies in science and engineering were also undertaken in this project. One involved the study of algorithms in robotics that guide large swarms of robots to perform tasks, such as shape formation, in a way that is mathematically justified. This could lead to new advances in the development of mobile sensors. Another study involved a collaboration with experimental physicists to explain how birds breathe using effective models and numerical simulations of fluid flow.
